description: From Middle English stool, stole, stol, from Old English stōl (“chair, seat, throne”), from Proto-West Germanic *stōl, from Proto-Germanic *stōlaz (“chair”) (compare West Frisian stoel, Dutch stoel, German Stuhl, Swedish/Norwegian/Danish stol, Finnish tuoli, Estonian tool), from Proto-Indo-European *stoh₂los (compare Lithuanian stálas, Russian стол (stol, “table”), Russian стул (stul, “chair”), Serbo-Croatian stol (“table”), Slovene stol (“chair”), Albanian kështallë (“crutch”), Ancient Greek στήλη (stḗlē, “block of stone used as a prop or buttress to a wall”)), from *steh₂- (“to stand”). More at stand.
The medical use derives from sense 2 (seat used for defecation).

definitionGroups.group: A seat, especially for one person and without armrests.

entries.meaning: A seat for one person without a back or armrests.
(now chiefly dialectal, Scotland) A seat with a back; a chair.
(now chiefly dialectal, Scotland, literally and figuratively) A throne.
(obsolete) A close-stool; a seat used for urination and defecation: a chamber pot, commode, outhouse seat, or toilet.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:chamber pot, Thesaurus:toilet, Thesaurus:bathroom

entries.meaning: (horticulture) A plant that has been cut down until its main stem is close to the ground, resembling a stool, to promote new growth.

examples: I provided the doctor with stool samples.

entries.meaning: (chiefly medicine) A production of feces or excrement, an act of defecation, stooling.
(archaic) A decoy; a portable piece of wood to which a pigeon is fastened to lure wild birds.
(nautical) A small channel on the side of a vessel, for the deadeyes of the backstays.
(US, dialect) Material, such as oyster shells, spread on the sea bottom for oyster spat to adhere to.

verbs.description: stool (third-person singular simple present stools, present participle stooling, simple past and past participle stooled)

entries.meaning: (chiefly medicine) To produce stool: to defecate.
(horticulture) To cut down (a plant) until its main stem is close to the ground, resembling a stool, to promote new growth.
A plant from which layers are propagated by bending its branches into the soil.

verbs.description: stool (third-person singular simple present stools, present participle stooling, simple past and past participle stooled)

entries.meaning: (agriculture) To ramify; to tiller, as grain; to shoot out suckers.
examples: I worked very hard in the copse of young ash, with my billhook and a shearing-knife; cutting out the saplings where they stooled too close together, making spars to keep for thatching, wall-crooks to drive into the cob, stiles for close sheep hurdles, and handles for rakes, and hoes, and two-bills, of the larger and straighter stuff.
